feed.title: JHM Lab.
feed.subtitle: Optimal Transport, Topology of Singularities, Physics.

entry.title: Integrating Newton-Weber Equations for Two Body Electrical Systems.

link.title: Integrating Newton-Weber Equations for Two Body Electrical Systems.

entry.summary: We continue to investigate Weber's force law, especially in the two body isolated system. In this post we record the current status of our python code for integrating the Newton-Weber equations of motion. We model the orbits of the stable (-1)+(-1) molecule within the Weber critical radius.

entry.title: Brief Remark on Coulomb vs Weber Escape Velocities.

link.title: Brief Remark on Coulomb vs Weber Escape Velocities.

entry.summary: We continue to investigate Weber's force law in the two body isolated system. In this post we briefly remark on the difference in escape velocities as computed by Coulomb and Weber's force law. Elementary post.

entry.title: Book Review. The Newton Papers by Susan Dry

link.title: Book Review. The Newton Papers by Susan Dry

entry.summary: Brief book review of Susan Dry's book about Newton's Manuscripts.

entry.title: Andre-Marie Ampere and Magnetism the Disposable Hypothesis

link.title: Andre-Marie Ampere and Magnetism the Disposable Hypothesis

entry.summary: [Under Construction] Brief remark on some ideas of Andre-Marie Ampere related to magnetism. Contains Assis' proof of the non-existence of magnetic monopoles as deduced from Ampere force law between current elements.

entry.title: Faraday Cages and Non Mathematics
entry.summary: [Under Construction] We discuss Faraday cages and the conspicuous absence of any proper mathematical derivation of their properties. This leads us to locate a source of confusion in the mathematical derivations of Faraday cage properties, and also leads us to review some erroneous alleged proofs. Ultimately we follow Assis and allege that the electric field inside regions bounded by conductors are not necessarily zero. In otherwords, there should be some motion in actress' tinsel inside the Faraday cage.
